utterance: JY: Right, underexplored space, right? There's tons of stuff that is out there that has not been tried um for redox active nucleophiles.

utterance: JL: Yeah. That strikes me as an interesting direction. Other other ideas around that? I mean, actually one one thing we could do is I think some of you are much more sort of coming from this research area. I know Jenny you and and Vic have have been working in this area. Um but and you explained a little bit about what you're doing. Um but David, uh are you also you're also working really in this area? Is that right?

utterance: DK: Uh yeah, I am. So I mentioned uh this uh work on sort of electrochemical pH swing as a way of doing CO2 separation. Um I'll say that the well, a couple things maybe, but in terms of the the one minute sort of idea or thing I'm thinking about, um you know, one thing I'll just throw out there is sort of thinking about ways of building sort of multifunctional uh either interfaces or materials that that sort of satisfy a number of the requirements that you need for CO2 separation, especially from air. So, um you know, so you you if you're doing say CO2 capture from air, you want something that's the oxygen that's not uh sort of sensitive to oxygen. Um you also want ideally something that's non-volatile. So if if you're doing this in an organic solvent, you're going to have issues with solvent loss. Um and then you want something that's uh redox active or that sort of responds to an electric field or potential. Um it will capture CO2 in one state and releases in another. And I'm curious as to whether it it makes any sense and you know, maybe in in typically what you would do is you pick the solvent and then you pick the active material and you sort of mix the two together, you know, you sort of build your system from there. Um I'm curious whether it makes sense to also think about trying to do or make sort of multifunctional sorbents that would fulfill a number of these requirements simultaneously. So for example, you start with uh like an ionic liquid, for example, which would not where you wouldn't have as much of an issue with uh volatility. And that is sort of your backbone and then you sort of build on top of that some sort of functionality or something either redox active or electric field responsive that does your that does sort of the switching uh sort of CO2 reversible CO2 binding release component. Um so I'm just sort of that's sort of what I'm I'm thinking about. Um is is whether you could build these sort of chemical uh these sort of new material systems and then you you you know, you put that in like a reactor um and one could then think about how effective it actually works in a in a real system, but yeah, that's that's one thought.

utterance: BG: Yeah, I um and shall would know this. And we can also uh improve the selectivity for CO2 and suppress it for oxygen to improve the sensitivity. But ultimately the redox active carrier is um you know, can be sensitive to oxygen and not necessarily maybe the electrolyte itself. But the um I think the main one of the main problems is um the ionic liquids are viscous, no matter you know, how you design them, they are going to be end up, you know, more viscous than your aqueous systems. And that's one challenge. And that kind of uh I think leads us into what kind of reactor designs can we have? Um I I yeah, I I think that's where I'll stop.

utterance: FB: I think it depends on the concentration, right? utterance: JL: I would warn that traditional membranes, the driving force is concentration gradient. And if your concentration on the air side is 410 ppm. It's really tough. So I don't want to shut down that. I'm not saying that. I'm just saying what traditional membrane problems would be.

utterance: JY: Jimmy, I wanted to add something that was on my list of things that I was thinking about during our quiet time, and that was, do we have to release it in all cases, right? So many of us in this room work on CO2 reduction. So one of the things that we've thought about is instead of reducing CO2, let's reduce the alkox. It would be an alkyl carbonate or carbamate, right? These are the products of CO2 capture with amines and hydroxides or alkoxides, respectively. And if we could just directly reduce it from there, that's a solution. And I would argue that some of the CO2 reduction alkaline cells basically do that, right? Because you're probably not reducing directly CO2, but you're reducing bicarbonate or carbonate at those pHs. And so I think that is an interesting approach, and so sort of just reshifting our thinking about CO2 reduction to reducing bound CO2 to some of these capture agents directly. And then related to that, I realized there's no geochemist in the room, but I know that in sequestration, right? There's certain minerals that are, this is my limited knowledge, that are stable to bury underground. And so can we electrochemically generate the precursors to these minerals to then directly synthesize them, capture, and then just bury that? And so those are just some of my thoughts, is that maybe we don't want to regenerate, we just want to make the product directly from the CO2 that's captured.

annotations.present new idea: JY presents a novel concept of reducing alkox instead of CO2, suggesting a shift in thinking about CO2 reduction by directly reducing bound CO2 to capture agents.

annotations.present new idea: JY introduces another new idea of electrochemically generating precursors to minerals for sequestration, capturing CO2 and directly synthesizing minerals to bury them.

But perhaps you could go to some other solid products, not solid calcium carbonate, but solid something else, which is potentially more useful than calcium carbonate. But one of the things I always thought, well, with some of the mineralization stuff is that, okay, you make a, you take the CO2 out, and now it's a solid that you can easily dispose of. utterance: BG: Um I have couple of things to throw. Um so we discussed about the thermodynamics and we touched upon kinetics. But I think within the within the thermodynamics we mostly focused on like enthalpic effects and not really like entropic effects. So the one thing that I have been fantasizing about is um since we're on the topic of electrochemical simulation. Um can we think about materials that would like have some induced entropic effects that would drive uh let's say the regeneration of CO2. I mean apart from enthalpic effects we can also have you know the entropic effects. Um and related to this, you know, we also discussed about these redux active CO2 carriers or redux active molecules, nucleophile. Um how about um designing the solvent around it. So you know this reduction potentials was too negative. I think um Jenny mentioned that. Well, I think we can design the interaction between these molecules with the environment to shift those potentials. So for example, I mean since I work with ionic liquids and deep eutectic solvents, I'm thinking about like hydrogen bonded systems that can interact with these species and shift the redox potentials so that you are in a better place and not like driving some other unwanted side reactions. Um and that has some entropy theme underneath it. Um I think those are the things that I thought about. And another thing is um we have worked with like encapsulated ionic liquids. So these had um these had graphene oxide material in its shell. So we thought okay, we have a conductive uh you know shell material. And initially we thought that we can use it at like energy storage, but it was kind of a naive idea because these are um you know, um kind of encapsulated liquids and they don't feel any voltage uh distribution. But in the context of CO2 capture and conversion or regeneration, um they can actually work as electrode materials where the ionic liquid or the core material can serve as like CO2 reservoirs. So you don't have to worry about um you know, have to bring CO2 to uh to the electrode surface. Um I mean you can tell me if it's a crazy idea but um something that that I think is something that we thought about in the past and kind of um you know, fits into this discussion I think.

annotations.present new idea: The speaker introduces the idea of considering entropic effects in addition to enthalpic effects for CO2 regeneration, which is a novel concept not explicitly discussed before.

annotations.expand on existing idea: The speaker builds upon the discussion of redox-active CO2 carriers by suggesting designing the solvent around them to shift redox potentials, expanding on Jenny's earlier point about reduction potentials being too negative.

annotations.present new idea: The speaker presents the idea of using encapsulated ionic liquids with a graphene oxide shell as electrode materials, where the ionic liquid core serves as CO2 reservoirs, which is a new concept in the context of the discussion.

So I've thought about it in in in from the from this uh CO2 uh CO2 electrochemical conversion uh standpoint of view, but I think it it might be analogous uh to you know, to CO2 capture if we could get the CO2, you know, to to to be in close proximity to these uh heterostructures.

utterance: JY: I have a question related to what you were saying about scale. Um, and I know some of you guys work with flow batteries too, which is probably related. annotations.explain or define term or concept: JY is asking to define the optimal scale for electrochemical processes.

utterance: FB: It depends on the process a little bit, um, and it depends upon where your cost is in the process. So, for example, you could sort of think of it as flow batteries are an easy example because you can separate power and energy. And so if you want an energy intensive application, the cost is dominated by what's in your tank. Um, if you have a power dominant application, it's dominated by what the what it cost you to make the reactor. Uh in these kind of systems, it's a bit different, right? And it would probably the way you'd want to think about it is throughput, right? So it's kind of what is the capital cost of your reactor? And then how much CO2 can you put through it because that's how you're going to make money, right? Um, and so that's how you should think about it. I mean, capital cost is important because, you know, bank ability, like someone's got to pay for the thing, right? And so if you think about like the first solar cells, they they kind of stunk, right? But they're still working and they're small and you can put them on your roof, right? Um, and so, you know, if for electrochemical systems, you could build at that sort of scale, local residential scale, and that allows you to do a lot more learning um as you go, and allows you also to make smaller products, which mean that there's less opportunities for for screw ups and a lot less money involved. Um, for a lot of sort of, you know, the larger scale systems like I guess carbon engineering, I mean, I think that system is is is pretty big in the base case. And I don't know how many of them they've built. I'm not so I've seen a lot of pretty pictures, but I don't know if I've actually seen a plant. Um, and so there's some some something about like, well, who's paying for this? How confident are you that this is going to work? Yada yada yada, this kind of stuff, right? So I don't think electrochemical systems can be infinitely small for sure. Um, but you could be a lot smaller than thermochemical systems. And actually if you look at scaling analysis, thermochemical systems can beat out electrochemical systems at large enough scale, right? Just because of heat integration, we're really good at that. Um, but at smaller scales, um the tables turn.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The speaker explains that the optimal scale for electrochemical processes depends on the process and where the cost is, using flow batteries as an example to illustrate the separation of power and energy costs.

annotations.provide supporting evidence: The speaker provides the example of early solar cells to support the idea that smaller, local-scale electrochemical systems can be viable even if they are not initially the most efficient, as they allow for more learning and smaller products.

annotations.expand on existing idea: The speaker expands on the discussion of scale by comparing electrochemical and thermochemical systems, noting that thermochemical systems can be more efficient at large scales due to heat integration, while electrochemical systems are better at smaller scales.
